Majority Leader Sen: Mitch McConnell's statement about following a longstanding tradition by not considering any Supreme Court nominee until after a new president is inaugurated in 2017.
McConnell: s reference to the "Biden rule," where Vice President Joe Biden in 1992 stated that the Senate should not act on filling a Supreme Court vacancy if it occurred in a presidential election year.
Examples of other politicians: such as Harry Reid in 2005 and Chuck Schumer in 2007, expressing similar sentiments about not confirming Supreme Court appointments in election years.
Analysis of historical data showing that: there have been only four Supreme Court seats opened up in election years, with the Senate confirming the president's nominee in three instances and refusing a nominee only once.
